metadata.title: Graphdiyne/main-group metal elements sandwich structure as a promising single atom electrocatalyst for nitrogen reduction: A theoretical investigation

Fig. 1 Top view and side view of BN-M-G. Green, gray and brown balls are B, N and C atoms, and balls in the middle of the interlayer represent metal atoms. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) BN-Mg-G; (b) BN-Ca-G; (c) Charge density difference diagram of the BN-Al-G structure, with yellow indicating charge accumulation and blue indicating charge depletion. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Adsorption energy of N2 on all BN-M-G structures. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Schematic diagram of two NRR paths of the end-on adsorption of N2. Fig 4 Fig. 5 ΔG(*N2 *NNH) free energy variations for different BN-M-G structures. Fig 5 Fig. 6 The Gibbs free energy profiles of NRR electrocatalyzed by BN-Mg-G (a) via the distal mechanism and (b) via alternating mechanism; (c) Intermediates geometries along the reaction (bond length unit: Å). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Gibbs free energy profiles of NRR electrocatalyzed by BN-Ca-G (a) via the distal mechanism and (b) via alternating mechanism; (c) Intermediates geometries along the reaction (bond length unit: Å). Fig 7 Fig. 8 The Gibbs free energy profiles of NRR electrocatalyzed by BN-Al-G (a) via the distal mechanism and (b) via alternating mechanism; (c) Intermediates geometries along the reaction (bond length unit: Å). Fig 8 Fig. 9 ΔG(*H) of H atom adsorption on BN-Mg-G, BNCa-G and BN-Al-G. Fig 9 Table 1 Binding energies Eb 1 (eV) of BN-M-G structure and Eb 2 (eV) of M-G structure. Table 2 BN-M-G ΔG *N2 (eV) dNN (Å) BN-Li-G -0.03 1.12 BN-K-G -0.02 1.11 BN-Mg-G -0.03 1.12 BN-Ca-G -0.04 1.12 BN-Al-G -0.59 1.15 Research Paper Graphdiyne/main-group metal elements sandwich structure as a promising single atom electrocatalyst for nitrogen reduction: A theoretical investigation Lina Yang Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Manqi Li Investigation Formal analysis a Domoina Holiharimanana Formal analysis Writing – review & editing b Tian Gao Formal analysis a Zhenhua Liu Formal analysis a Shiyao Liu Formal analysis a Hao Sun Conceptualization Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Supervision a ⁎ a Institute of Functional Material Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, National & Local United Engineering Lab for Power Battery, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin 130024, PR China Institute of Functional Material Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry National & Local United Engineering Lab for Power Battery Northeast Normal University Changchun Jilin 130024 PR China aInstitute of Functional Material Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, National & Local United Engineering Lab for Power Battery, Northeast Normal University, Changchun, Jilin 130024, PR China b School of Chemical and Biomolecular Science, Southern Illinois University Carbondale, IL 62901, United States School of Chemical and Biomolecular Science Southern Illinois University Carbondale IL 62901 United States bSchool of Chemical and Biomolecular Science, Southern Illinois University Carbondale, IL 62901, United States ⁎ Corresponding author. In an effort to limit global warming and CO2 emission, ammonia has become a viable hydrogen carrier and alternative fuel. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction (e-NRR) has gained much attention as a mean to produce ammonia under mild reaction conditions. Consequently, the advancement of highly efficient and selective catalysts for e-NRR is key in the development of clean energy. Based on the "chainmail" protection catalyst proposed by recent studies, we used first-principles calculations to design a catalyst composed of a single main-group metal atom sandwiched between BN-doped graphdiyne and graphdiyne sheets. The structures, labeled BN-M-G (M = Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca and Al), were investigated as potential catalysts for e-NRR. After screening the most favorable configurations for N2 adsorption and activation, we further explored their e-NRR catalytic properties including efficiency and selectivity. Our results show that the optimal e-NRR path on BN-Mg-G and BN-Al-G is the alternating path with a limiting voltage of -0.47 V and -0.67 V, respectively. In contrast to the competing reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), both catalysts show high selectivity towards e-NRR. Our work shows that through rational design and electronic structure regulation, main-group-metals-based catalysts can have comparable catalytic activity as transition metal catalysts. This present study offers new insights for the development of low-cost and environmetally-friendly main group metal catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Graphdiyne Nitrogen reduction reaction Electrocatalysis Main group metals Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is a carbon-free clean energy, which has a wide application in the production of fertilizers and household products [1–4]. At industrial scale, NH3 is currently produced through Haber-Bosch process (HBP), using iron or ruthenium catalysts. During the process, N2 and H2 molecules decompose into N and H atoms, which then couple to form NH3 [5]. However, due to the high stability of NN bond, HBP is performed under harsh reaction conditions [6] which requires a large amount of energy and produce abundant greenhouse gasses [7,8]. In comparison, electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction reaction (e-NRR) is a sustainable, environmentally-friendly and efficient way to produce NH3 [9,10]. Noble metal catalysts, such as Ru(0001) surface, are known to be efficient catalysts for e-NRR. High costs and scarcity of noble metals, however, limit their application on a large scale. Single atom catalysts (SACs) have been developed to replace bulk catalysts in recent years from the perspectives of catalytic activity and atomic efficiency [11,12]. The progress from bulk catalysts to single atom catalysts is a milestone in the history of catalysts. In the development of single atom catalysts, transition metals have received widespread attention and in-depth research due to their unique d electronic structures [13–18]. However, research on SACs for the main group metal elements is still limited. Studies have shown that the main group elements can optimize the binding strength and promote catalytic performance [19]. Therefore, when the main group elements, such as alkali metals and alkaline earth metals are loaded on a suitable substrate, they may also show excellent catalytic activity. The systematic research in this field will promote the development and design of more environmentally friendly and economical catalysts. The innovation from transition metal to main group metal SACs could be another important breakthrough in the development process of catalysts. Herein, we investigated the e-NRR potential of a series of SACs with main-group metal (M) atoms sandwiched between BN-doped GDY and GDY sheets. These catalysts are denoted BN-M-G (M=Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca, and Al). The stability, conductivity, catalytic activity and selectivity of the catalyst were analyzed. Two catalysts, BN-Mg-G and BN-Al-G, showed high catalytic activity and selectivity toward e-NRR by inhibiting HER – a competing reaction. The minimum limit potential of e-NRR for BN-Mg-G catalyst is -0.47 V, and that for BN-Al-G catalyst is -0.67 V. 2 Calculation methods All calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [20]. Spin polarization density functional theory (DFT) was used for the calculation, and the exchange-correlation energy was treated by PBE functional [21]. The projection enhanced wave (PAW) method is used to describe the electron-ion interaction [22]. The cutoff energy of the plane wave base group is 450 eV. The energy and force convergence thresholds for all self-consistent optimizations are 1 × 10–5 and 0.02 eV A-1, respectively. The DFT-D2 method is used to deal with Van der Waals (vdW) interactions. [23] The supercell (2 × 2 × 1) of BN-doped GDY and GDY was used to simulate the formation of sandwich structure by single atom covering of main group metal (M). The vacuum layer space of 20 Å is used for calculation. A 3 × 3 × 1 Brillouin K-point grid [24] was used to optimize the structure. The Bader charge is calculated using a 7 × 7 × 1 K-point grid [25]. The binding energy (Eb) of adding single M atom to the substrate is calculated according to formula 2.1. (2.1) E b = E M − s u b − E s u b − E M where, Esub and EM-sub are the individual base energy and the total base energy when M single atoms are added, respectively. EM is the energy of an isolated M atom. Using the hydrogen electrode (CHE) model established by Peterson et al. [26,27], the free energy diagram (ΔG) of NRR is calculated. (2.2) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G p H In Formula 2.2, ΔE, ΔEZPE and ΔS at each step are the electron energy difference, the zero point energy change and the entropy change, respectively. ΔGU =−eU is the change in free energy associated with the electrode potential U. ΔGpH is the free energy correction of pH, calculated by KBT × ln10 × pH(pH = 0 in this paper). T at room temperature, 298.15 K, ΔEZPE and ΔS are calculated from the vibration frequency. For gas phase molecules, zero-point energy and entropy are obtained from the NIST database [28]. The limit potential (UL) is calculated from UL = -ΔGmax/e. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability of BN-M-G Firstly, the stability of the sandwich structure formed by six main group metal atoms (Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca and Al) between BN-doped GDY and GDY is studied. The top and side views of the BN-M-G structure are displayed in Fig. 1 . In all sandwich structures, M atoms cause the deformation of BN sheet, causing adjacent B atoms to protrude from the BN sheet. Before further discussion, we calculate the binding energy of M atoms to two sheets in all BN-M-G systems. It can be seen from the value of Eb1 in Table 1 that the binding energies are all significantly negative, indicating that a strong chemical bond is formed between the single M atom and the sandwich structure. More negative Eb 1 implies that compared with the M single atoms deposited on the single layer GDY, the sandwich structures bind the M single atoms more tightly, thereby making the system more stable. In order to further evaluate stability of the catalyst, taking BN-Mg-G as an example, molecular dynamics (MD) simulation is carried out for 10 ps in the NVT ensemble, with 1 fs time step at 298 K. The energy and temperature change is shown in Fig. S1, their small fluctuations demonstrate the good kinetic stability of catalyst. Next, we further analyzed the charge density differences of the catalysts, taking BN-Mg-G, BNCa-G and BN-Al-G as examples, whose charge density differences are illustrated in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that there is a notable charge transfer between metal atom and the surrounding B atoms. In Fig. 2(a), electron transfer from the Mg atom to the B atom can be clearly observed, and the Bader charge calculation shows that the Mg atom loses 1.65e and the metal becomes positively charged in BN-Mg-G. The charge of the B atom closest to the Mg atom increases, making it easier for the B atom to adsorb and activate N2 after gaining electrons, which is conducive to the further occurrence of NRR. Similarly, apparent electron transfer from Ca and Mg atoms to B atoms can also be observed from Fig. 2(b) and (c). The calculations show that B atom gains electrons in the both structures, while Ca and Al atom lose 1.42e and 2.24e, respectively. The obvious electron accumulations on B atoms demonstrate the potential for N2 adsorption and activation. 3.2 Adsorption and activation of N2 on BN-M-G The initial step of NRR is N2 adsorption on catalyst, and the efficient activation of NN triple bond is crucial for N2 conversion to NH3. Therefore, adsorption of N2 molecule on BN-M-G structure was firstly studied in this section. Since B atom activates N2 by transferring electrons to 1π* orbital of N2 molecule, the site with the most electrons was selected as the adsorption site of N2 molecule by Bader charge analysis. The N2 can be adsorbed on the catalyst via two feasible adsorption configurations, i.e. end-on and side-on, where N2 interacts with the substrate with one N atom and π bond, respectively. The computational adsorption energy of N2 in two adsorption configurations demonstrates that N2 tends to be adsorbed on BN-M-G in an end-on configuration. From Fig. 3 , all the sandwich structures except BNNa-G can stably adsorb N2, so the following study on catalytic performance will exclude BNNa-G. Through further calculation, the free energy of N2 adsorption on BN-M-G (ΔG*N2) is obtained, as shown in Table 2 . It can be seen that N2 adsorption is a spontaneous process (ΔG*N2 < 0). At the same time, NN bond length is 1.11–1.15 Å after adsorption, whereas it is 1.10 Å in free N2 molecule, indicating that the inert bond of N2 is activated to some extent (Table 2). 3.3 Nitrogen reduction reaction mechanism In order to assess the catalytic performance of BN-M-G on NRR, we investigated the possible pathways for the end-on adsorption of N2, namely the distal pathway and the alternating pathway, which involve six successive hydrogenation reactions. In the distal path, as shown in Fig. 4 , the proton-electron pair firstly reacts with the N atom, which is not bonded to B atom, releasing the first NH3 molecule. Afterward, continuous hydrogenation occurs on the N atom adsorbed to B atom, resulting in the second NH3 molecule. In the alternating path, two NH3 molecules are produced and released by alternately hydrogenating two N atoms in the N2 molecule. Next, we will simulate and analyze the detailed NRR mechanism after adsorption of N2 molecules on various catalysts. According to previous theoretical studies [29], we first calculated the free energy ΔG(*N2 *NNH) of the initial hydrogenation step to preliminarily screen potential NRR catalyst candidates. The limiting potential (-0.98 V) of the Ru(0001) was chosen as the standard reference to evaluate the electrocatalytic NRR activity of the catalyst [29]. If the ΔG(*N2 *NNH) of the catalyst is less than 0.98 eV, it is considered a qualified candidate for electrocatalytic NRR. As shown in Fig. 5 , the catalysts sandwiched with Mg, Ca, and Al with a free energy change less than 0.98 eV in the first hydrogenation step meet the preliminary screening criteria for NRR catalysts. Next, the distal and alternate mechanisms of NRR for the three catalysts are further calculated and analyzed. The Gibbs free energy profiles of NRR electrocatalyzed BN-Mg-G, BNCa-G and BN-Al-G are plotted in Fig. 6 , 7 and 8 , respectively, and the intermediate configurations of each reaction step as well. 3.3.1 NRR mechanism catalyzed by BN-MG-G As shown in Figure 6(c), N2 molecule is initially adsorbed on catalyst surface in an end-on configuration and the NN bond is extended to 1.12 Å. In the first hydrogenation step, N2 interacts with the B atom to form B-N bond with a bond length of 1.50 Å, while the NN bond is stretched to 1.25 Å. This step is endothermic and requires overcoming the free energy barrier of 0.47 eV to form *NNH. The second hydrogenation step is the formation of *NNH2, the free energy is reduced by 0.29 eV, and the distance between the two N atoms is increased to 1.29 Å. The subsequent hydrogenation of *NNH2 to produce the first NH3 molecule consumes a Gibbs free energy of 0.33 eV. When NH3 molecule escapes from the substrate, the remaining N atom remains interacting with BN-Mg-G via the B-N bond of 1.43 Å. Then, in the fourth protonation step to generate *NH, 1.72 eV of free energy was released. When a proton-electron pair reacts with *NH to generate *NH2, N-B bond is activated, and free energy is reduced by 2.59 eV. The NH2 hydrogenation to the second NH3 molecule consumes 0.49 eV of energy. Finally, when 0.46 eV of energy is overcome, another NH3 molecule can be desorbed from the catalyst. It can be seen that the rate-limiting step in the distal mechanism is the process of *NH2 reduction to *NH3, accompanied with an energy barrier of 0.49 eV. When BN-Mg-G electrocatalyzed NRR follows an alternating pathway, the proton-electron pairs react with both N atoms alternately, leading to the formation of two NH3 molecules. The first hydrogenation step exhibits similarity to the distal pathway, which requires a barrier of 0.47 eV to generate *NNH. The second hydrogenation reaction produces *NHNH, in which the free energy is reduced by 0.56 eV and NN bond is extended to 1.32 Å. Next, *NHNH is continuously hydrogenated to generate *NHNH2, *NH2 NH2 and *NH2, with an energy decrease of 0.63 eV, an increase of 0.07 eV, and a decrease of 1.95 eV, respectively. It can be seen that the potential-determining step (PDS) is the first hydrogenation *NN → *NNH for alternating mechanism, accompanied with an energy barrier of 0.47 eV, slightly lower than the PDS barrier of distal mechanism. Thus, the NRR limiting potentials across the distal and alternating mechanisms on the BN-Mg-G catalyst are -0.49 V and -0.47 V, respectively. 3.3.2 NRR mechanism catalyzed by BN-CA-G As shown in Fig. 7, when the BNCa-G catalyzed NRR occurs via the distal mechanism, N atom forms a bond of 1.50 Å with B atom and the NN bond undergoes elongation to 1.25 Å in the first hydrogenation step, which is endothermic and requires overcoming a barrier of 0.89 eV to form *NNH. In the hydrogenation of *NNH to *NNH2, the Gibbs free energy is reduced by 0.07 eV, and distance between the two N atoms is increased to 1.30 Å. The subsequent hydrogenation of *NNH2 to produce the first NH3 molecule consumes a Gibbs free energy of 0.16 eV, and the remaining B-N bond is 1.45 Å. Then, in the fourth protonation step to generate *NH, 1.85 eV of energy is released. When a proton-electron pair reacts with *NH, N-B bond is activated and free energy is reduced by 2.37 eV. The hydrogenation of *NH2 to NH3 molecule requires an energy of 0.49 eV. Finally, the second NH3 molecule is released from BNCa-G when free energy of the system drops by 0.14 eV. It can be seen that the PDS in distal path is generation of *NNH, with an energy barrier of 0.89 eV. When NRR follows an alternating mechanism, the proton-electron pairs take turns attacking two N atoms until two NH3 molecules are formed. The first hydrogenation step follows the identical process as distal mechanism, which requires a free energy barrier of 0.89 eV to generate *NNH. The second hydrogenation produces *NHNH, the free energy is reduced by 0.56 eV, and NN bond is extended to 1.32 Å. The ΔG of the subsequent hydrogenation reaction is -0.25 eV(*NHNH → *NHNH2), -0.15 eV(*NHNH2 → *NH2 NH2), -2.15 eV(*NH2 NH2 → *NH2 + NH3), and 0.49 eV(*NH3), respectively. Therefore, NRR limit potential on the BNCa-G catalyst through both the distal and alternating mechanisms is -0.89 V. 3.3.3 NRR mechanism catalyzed by BN-AL-G The Gibbs free energy of NRR electrocatalyzed by BN-Al-G and the structure of the intermediates are shown in Fig. 8. The NN bond is stretched to 1.15 Å from 1.10 Å in the end-on adsorption configuration, indicating that NN bond is activated. For distal mechanism, the first hydrogenation is endothermic with an energy of 0.27 eV forming *NNH, where N atoms form a 1.50 Å B-N bond with B atoms, and NN bond is stretched to 1.26 Å. The hydrogenation of *NNH to *NNH2 requires overcoming a free energy of 0.28 eV and NN bond length is increased to 1.31 Å. The subsequent *NNH2 hydrogenation to produce the first NH3 molecule consumes a small free energy of 0.08 eV. During the fourth protonation step to generate *NH, 2.48 eV of free energy was released. When the proton-electron pair attacks *NH to produce *NH2, N-B bond is activated, and free energy of the system is decreased by 2.48 eV. The hydrogenation of NH2 to the second NH3 molecule overcomes the highest barrier of 0.95 eV. Finally, the second NH3 molecule is desorbed from BN-Al-G, endothermic with 0.84 eV of free energy. It can be seen that the PDS in the distal mechanism is *NH2 reduction to *NH3, with an energy barrier of 0.95 eV. For alternating mechanism, the first hydrogenation requires overcoming an energy barrier of 0.27 eV to generate *NNH. The second hydrogenation reaction produces *NHNH, the free energy is reduced by 0.22 eV, and NN bond is stretched to 1.32 Å. The ΔG values for the subsequent hydrogenation reactions are -1.13 eV(*NHNH →*NHNH2), 0.67 eV(*NHNH2 →*NH2 NH2), -2.46 eV(*NH2 NH2 →*NH2 + NH3), and -0.24 eV (*NH3), respectively. It can be seen that *NHNH2 hydrogenation to *NH2 NH2 has the largest ΔG value (0.67 eV), representing the PDS of reaction. Finally, a free energy of 0.84 eV is required for NH3 desorption from BN-Al-G. This is much lower than the experimentally confirmed desorption energy barrier of NH3 molecules on boron carbide nanosheets (1.73 eV) [30], demonstrating that it is promising for NH3 molecules to be released easily from BN-Al-G surface. Therefore, the NRR limiting potentials via the distal and alternating mechanisms on the BN-Al-G catalyst are -0.95 V and -0.67 V, respectively. It is obvious that the alternating pathway dominates the NRR electrocatalyzed by BN-Al-G. In summary, the limiting potential of the BN-Mg-G electrocatalyzed NRR is -0.49 V for the distal mechanism and -0.47 V for alternating one. The BN-Ca-G electrocatalyzed NRR requires the same limiting potential of -0.89 V for both mechanisms. The limiting potentials on BN-Al-G catalyst are -0.95 V and -0.67 V for the distal and alternating mechanisms, respectively. Due to its lowest limiting potentials, BN-Mg-G may exhibit the highest catalytic efficiency among all the BN-M-G catalysts. 3.4 Hydrogen evolution reaction analysis Since the entire NRR takes place in an aqueous environment with protons supplied by the solution, HER should be considered as it may compete with the NRR and reduce the Faraday efficiency (FE) of the target product. For a catalyst, the closer the adsorption energy of H atom (ΔG(*H)) is to HER equilibrium potential (∼0 V), the greater the selectivity of HER exhibits. Therefore, we calculated the adsorption energy of H atom on BN-Mg-G, BNCa-G and BN-Al-G, and the optimized geometries of H atom adsorption on the three catalysts are displayed in Fig. S2. The selectivity was then evaluated by comparing the ΔG(*H) values with the maximum energy barriers during the NRR process. It is shown in Fig. 9 that the ΔG(*H) of BNCa-G is -0.51 eV, whose absolute value is lower than the maximum energy barrier (0.89 eV) for NRR, indicating high selectivity of HER. Therefore, the BNCa-G structure is more inclined towards HER but does not meet the NRR catalyst screening. The ΔG(*H) of BN-Mg-G is -1.01 eV, and its absolute value is much larger than the maximum energy barrier (0.49 eV) of NRR, so BN-Mg-G has excellent NRR selectivity and is a promising NRR catalyst with high FE. Similarly, BN-Al-G exhibits higher selectivity for NRR compared with HER because the ΔG(*H) of -1.85 eV, is much larger than the maximum energy barrier (0.95 eV) in NRR. 4 Summary In this work, the sandwich structures (BN-M-G) formed by BN-doped GDY and GDY with insertion of different main-group metal atom (Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca and Al) were designed. Their performance for N2 activation and reduction was investigated by first principles calculations. N2 molecule tends to attach with B atom in an end-on configuration, and the inert NN bond is efficiently activated by withdrawing electrons from the interacting B atom. The calculations of NRR mechanisms reveal that BN-Mg-G and BN-Al-G exhibit excellent performance among all the catalysts. It is found that the BN-Mg-G electrocatalyzed NRR mainly proceeds via an alternating pathway, with the corresponding limit potential being as low as -0.47 V. The limiting potential is -0.67 V for the dominant alternating mechanism of BN-Al-G electrocatalyzed NRR. Both catalysts exhibit high selectivity for NRR compared to HER. Therefore, it can be speculated that BN-Mg-G and BN-Al-G are promising NRR electrocatalyst candidates. It is noteworthy that the limiting potential of BN-Mg-G (-0.47 V) is even lower than that of the transition state metal catalyst BNCr-G (calculated limiting potential: -0.63 V) screened in our previous work [31]. This work not only sheds a light on the design of NRR electrocatalysts with high efficiency and selectivity, but also contributes to promoting the development of main group metal SACs. coredata.dc:description: In an effort to limit global warming and CO2 emission, ammonia has become a viable hydrogen carrier and alternative fuel. Electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction (e-NRR) has gained much attention as a mean to produce ammonia under mild reaction conditions. Consequently, the advancement of highly efficient and selective catalysts for e-NRR is key in the development of clean energy. Based on the "chainmail" protection catalyst proposed by recent studies, we used first-principles calculations to design a catalyst composed of a single main-group metal atom sandwiched between BN-doped graphdiyne and graphdiyne sheets. The structures, labeled BN-M-G (M = Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca and Al), were investigated as potential catalysts for e-NRR. After screening the most favorable configurations for N2 adsorption and activation, we further explored their e-NRR catalytic properties including efficiency and selectivity. Our results show that the optimal e-NRR path on BN-Mg-G and BN-Al-G is the alternating path with a limiting voltage of -0.47 V and -0.67 V, respectively. In contrast to the competing reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), both catalysts show high selectivity towards e-NRR. Our work shows that through rational design and electronic structure regulation, main-group-metals-based catalysts can have comparable catalytic activity as transition metal catalysts. This present study offers new insights for the development of low-cost and environmetally-friendly main group metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Graphdiyne/main-group metal elements sandwich structure as a promising single atom electrocatalyst for nitrogen reduction: A theoretical investigation
